explanation: The if condition used `or [".#","#."]` which is a non-empty list and thus always truthy, so the condition always evaluated to True and the program always printed "No". I fixed it by comparing [s1, s2] to the second pattern as well (i.e. repeating the comparison). This follows the same pattern used in fixes where each comparison must be explicit instead of relying on a bare truthy value.
fixed_code:
s1 = input()
s2 = input()

if [s1, s2] == ["#.",".#"] or [s1, s2] == [".#","#."]:
    print('No')
    exit()
else:
    print('Yes')
